moves.1. e4:
Even if I have lost the game in a deplorable way, I think that this is one of my most interesting games for the rich tactic possibilities in the midgame. 
Black makes very questionable choices in a very tense situation, and finally loses, but... was the sac sound? Could black have survived or even won?
If you can provide an answer, I would appreciate you to do so.
moves.2... Bf5: I can't conceive to play this opening with the lsb into the pawn's chain, but I know it is playable and even considered better.
moves.3. Bb5+: Not very recommendable, but not disatrous (IMO).
moves.3... c6: Another option is Nc6. This move deprives the knight of a good square, but it can go to d7 anyway, and it is not badly placed.
moves.4. Be2: White didn't lose a tempo, since my best option will be to play c5, sooner or later, so c6 would have been a loss of tempo.
moves.4... e6 5. d4 a6: This is obviously in order to play c5 (avoiding the bishop's check). Black has not a wonderful game, but its objectives are clear: to catch up in developement, and there are only few ways to do it. And it is very difficult for white to avoid it.
moves.6. Nf3: A promising procedure for white is g4, f4... a quick expansion on the kingside. I am prepared to cope with it, anyway.
moves.6... h6: ...and this is in order to keep the lsb in case of Nh5. This will happen if the black queen wants to go to the kingside. Ok, too many pawn's move in the opening, but the position is still solid.
moves.7. O-O c5: Now black's queenside developement is assured. Another pawn's move...
moves.8. b3: White sees no quick attack (c4!?). He is somewhat threatening Ba6, if this can be considered instead of Be3.
moves.8... Nc6: Thank you for the tempo, white.
moves.9. c3: Ah, ok, white's plan is to play slowly, building a fortress with pawns. Ok.
moves.9... b5: Let's push them, then. My kingside is blocked, but the game is on the queenside, and my dsb is acting from its very spot, as long as the bg8 knight is patient.
moves.10. Re1: Piling a futile defence, since e5 is invulnerable in most lines.
moves.10... Qb6: This move adds pressure on the black diagonal, specially d4. Since I cannot develop my other pieces, I do it with my queen.
moves.11. Bd3: Thematic. Black cannot afford BxB, since my strenght is the pawn chain.
moves.11... Bg4: Depriving d4 of one of its defenders.
moves.12. Be3: Adding another one. Tension is building, but for white dxc5 is not good.
moves.12... Bxf3: The idea is to keep the pressure on d4. In this opening, I know my white bishop will be exchanged, eventually, so I decide to exchange it before Nb1 goes to d2 and makes the exchange useless.
moves.13. Qxf3: Now I can take the pawn and give some air to my dsb.
moves.13... cxd4 14. Bd2:
By taking back the pawn with c3xd4, the natural move, I'd have a little countergame with Nb4, threatening Kc2 forking the rooks or to exchange the white's lsb. With Bxd4, I could develop my bishop in c4.  
But now the firework starts.
moves.14... dxc3: This seems to be bad, since I am helping white's developement. But if Bc5, b5!, so I am somewhat forced. I can't delay my developement any further.
moves.15. Bxc3: Nxc3 would have been better, even if black had countermoves, like Nd4, or Bc5, or Bb4.
moves.15... Bc5: Finally developing the dsb. Black is catching up in developement very quickly, as it often happens in the Scandinavian.
moves.16. a3: Threatening b4, kicking my bishop, that could have gone to d4, etc. But I started to think about some tactic...
moves.16... d4: Now I have to be very careful, since the queen is x-raying my rook (with check!).
moves.17. Be4: With a nasty fork threat on c6.
moves.17... Nxe5: OOOOhhhhh!....:-))) This was my plan from the Bc5 move. It protects c6 and the queen must abandon the support of the white diagonal. I knew it has a very nice place to go to...
moves.18. Qg3: This one. Note that the knight is threatened, as is the g7 pawn. But I considered that the pawn was poisoned. On purpose, I afford to have two free pieces under attack, plus a weak spot. He has only the dsb uner threat. But in chess you have ONLY ONE MOVE at a time...
moves.18... dxc3:
This was my bet. If the queen leaves, Bxf2+. No problem if white goes BxR, since it gives me a tempo I can use for a lot of nice things, like pushing the pawn to c2! Not enough to win, but still threatening. 
Now: is Bxf2+ enough to go for it? Remember the white queen can be on g7, threatening the rook and then the knight with check. 
Of course, QxN is also possible, but then Bxf2+ is still there.
moves.19. Bxa8: A rook is gone (but material is equal!), and I cannot go Bxf2+. And I still have two problems: the knight and the pawn. But I had a trick in my sleeve... or at least I thought so.
moves.19... Ng4:
OOOOOOOOhhhhhh!!!
If QxN, Bxf2+ and then I can take the rook... but I wouldn't!
I need the bishop to be ready to come back to d4 in order to threaten the queen and save the rook. Then, I'm threatening c2, winning the knight or the rook a1.
